pull_request.title: feat: add syncset controller, feat: syncset readiness
pull_request.body:
> in support of the [sync set proposal](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1ZbXaEh7v_HcgrRu7N-kEucU2pXyq1Rt7cSmmFOBN2q8/edit#heading=h.paw4op9i091a)

* Adds a `syncset_controller` and necessary changes for tracking `readiness` from syncsets and config resources
* Introduces a reconciler for data expectations
* Implements "TryCancel" for data expectations
* Improves the CacheManager to distinguish the watch errors for the gvks it's given
* Adds the SyncSet CRD to the manifest.

@@ -184,3 +195,30 @@ func Test_ExpectationsMgr_DeletedSyncSets(t *testing.T) {
 		})
 	}
 }
+
+// Test_ExpectationsMgr_missedInformers verifies that the pruner can handle a scenario
+// where the readiness tracker's state will never match the informer cache events.
+func Test_ExpectationsMgr_missedInformers(t *testing.T) {
+	ctx, cancelFunc := context.WithCancel(context.Background())
+
+	// because we will use a separate lister for the tracker from the mgr client
+	// the contents of the readiness tracker will be superset of the contents of the mgr's client
+	tl := fakes.NewTestLister(
+		fakes.WithSyncSets([]*syncsetv1alpha1.SyncSet{
+			fakes.SyncSetFor("syncset-1", []schema.GroupVersionKind{podGVK, configMapGVK}),
+		}),
+	)
+	em, _ := setupTest(ctx, t, testOptions{testLister: tl})
+
+	require.Eventually(t, func() bool {
+		return em.tracker.SyncSourcesSatisfied()
+	}, timeout, tick, "waiting on sync sources to get satisfied")
+
+	em.pruneNotWatchedGVKs()
comment.body: Considering the ExpectationsPruner is a runnable and is hooked into the manager IRL, we'd have a more realistic test if we ran the EP in the manager.  This test is already creating a manager, so it's just a question of plumbing the right stuff.

+)
+
+var scheme *runtime.Scheme
+
+func init() {
+	scheme = runtime.NewScheme()
+	if err := v1beta1.AddToScheme(scheme); err != nil {
+		panic(err)
+	}
+	if err := syncsetv1alpha1.AddToScheme(scheme); err != nil {
+		panic(err)
+	}
+}
+
+// Fake lister to use for readiness testing.

comment.body:
I think we can replace this entire `TestLister` with a pre-existing type included in `controller-runtime`: https://pkg.go.dev/sigs.k8s.io/controller-runtime/pkg/client/fake#ClientBuilder.WithLists

You can instantiate it with lists of objects and it's an in-memory data store.  Seems very similar.

There is a similar type in `pkg/controller/mutators/core/reconciler_test.go`:

https://github.com/open-policy-agent/gatekeeper/blob/3a83700f287e73376ba264db1cc75d14dd0da8f8/pkg/controller/mutators/core/reconciler_test.go#L81-L172

Please make an issue and add a comment above the version in `reconciler_test.go` that we should investigate replacing that re-implementation with the one from controller-runtime.

comment.body:
You don't need to change it now if you don't want to, but this is actually a good use of the golang "super tiny variable name" convention.

Because we would do:

```
tr := testResources{}
```

it's very obvious what this variable is.  This is clear and reduces visual noise.

When it was more like:

```
tr := funcThatDoesNotHaveTestResourcesInTheName()
```

you can see how it was less obvious.

gvkErr := watch.NewErrorList()

pull_request.title: feat: Gator sync verify support
pull_request.body:
**What this PR does / why we need it**:
Certain templates require replicating into OPA to enable correct evaluation. These templates can use the annotation `metadata.gatekeeper.sh/requires-sync-data` to indicate which resources need to be synced. This template annotation is descriptive, not prescriptive. The prescription of which resources to sync is done in `SyncSet` resources and/or the Gatekeeper `Config` resource. The management of these various requirements can get challenging as the number of templates requiring replicated data increases. 

`gator sync verify` aims to mitigate this challenge by enabling the user to verify their sync configuration is correct. The user passes in any number of Constraint Templates, SyncSets, and Gatekeeper Config objects (although in practice only one Config object should exist), and the command will determine which requirements enumerated by the Constraint Templates are unfulfilled by the given SyncSet(s) and Config(s).

[PRD](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1mBvy6Y7TDyZswdYlFBHB3Mi2irLVqga_7ZoZvfPIU0A/edit)

**Which issue(s) this PR fixes** *(optional, using `fixes #<issue number>(, fixes #<issue_number>, ...)` format, will close the issue(s) when the PR gets merged)*:
xref #2393 

**Special notes for your reviewer**:
Put ToSyncSet and ToConfig alongside ToConfig; however I did notice some type conversion in [individual command code](https://github.com/open-policy-agent/gatekeeper/blob/master/pkg/gator/expand/expand.go#L232) and I could see that being more correct since this won't be used anywhere else
Wasn't quite sure how to handle discovery results via stdin as they're not Kubernetes unstructureds; would welcome any thoughts there :)

pull_request.title: feat: Gator sync verify support
pull_request.body:
**What this PR does / why we need it**:
Certain templates require replicating into OPA to enable correct evaluation. These templates can use the annotation `metadata.gatekeeper.sh/requires-sync-data` to indicate which resources need to be synced. This template annotation is descriptive, not prescriptive. The prescription of which resources to sync is done in `SyncSet` resources and/or the Gatekeeper `Config` resource. The management of these various requirements can get challenging as the number of templates requiring replicated data increases. 

`gator sync verify` aims to mitigate this challenge by enabling the user to verify their sync configuration is correct. The user passes in any number of Constraint Templates, SyncSets, and Gatekeeper Config objects (although in practice only one Config object should exist), and the command will determine which requirements enumerated by the Constraint Templates are unfulfilled by the given SyncSet(s) and Config(s).

[PRD](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1mBvy6Y7TDyZswdYlFBHB3Mi2irLVqga_7ZoZvfPIU0A/edit)

**Which issue(s) this PR fixes** *(optional, using `fixes #<issue number>(, fixes #<issue_number>, ...)` format, will close the issue(s) when the PR gets merged)*:
xref #2393 

**Special notes for your reviewer**:
Put ToSyncSet and ToConfig alongside ToConfig; however I did notice some type conversion in [individual command code](https://github.com/open-policy-agent/gatekeeper/blob/master/pkg/gator/expand/expand.go#L232) and I could see that being more correct since this won't be used anywhere else
Wasn't quite sure how to handle discovery results via stdin as they're not Kubernetes unstructureds; would welcome any thoughts there :)

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -427,6 +427,80 @@ However, not including the `namespace` definition in the call to `gator expand`
 error expanding resources: error expanding resource nginx-deployment: failed to mutate resultant resource nginx-deployment-pod: matching for mutator Assign.mutations.gatekeeper.sh /always-pull-image failed for  Pod my-ns nginx-deployment-pod: failed to run Match criteria: namespace selector for namespace-scoped object but missing Namespace
 ```
 
+## The `gator sync verify` subcommand
+
+Certain templates require [replicating data](sync.md) into OPA to enable correct evaluation. These templates can use the annotation `metadata.gatekeeper.sh/requires-sync-data` to indicate which resources need to be synced. The annotation contains a json object representing a list of requirements, each of which contains a list of one or more equivalence sets. Each of these equivalence sets has `groups`, `versions`, and `kinds` fields; any group-version-kind combination within an equivalence set within a requirement should be considered sufficient to satisfy that requirement. For example (comments added for clarity):
+```
+[
+  [ // Requirement 1
+    { // Equivalence set 1
+      "groups": ["group1", group2"]
+      "versions": ["version1", "version2", "version3"]
+      "kinds": ["kind1", "kind2"]
+    },
+    { // Equivalence Set 2
+      "groups": ["group3", group4"]
+      "versions": ["version3", "version4"]
+      "kinds": ["kind3", "kind4"]
+    }

pull_request.body:
**What this PR does / why we need it**:
Certain templates require replicating into OPA to enable correct evaluation. These templates can use the annotation `metadata.gatekeeper.sh/requires-sync-data` to indicate which resources need to be synced. This template annotation is descriptive, not prescriptive. The prescription of which resources to sync is done in `SyncSet` resources and/or the Gatekeeper `Config` resource. The management of these various requirements can get challenging as the number of templates requiring replicated data increases. 

`gator sync verify` aims to mitigate this challenge by enabling the user to verify their sync configuration is correct. The user passes in any number of Constraint Templates, SyncSets, and Gatekeeper Config objects (although in practice only one Config object should exist), and the command will determine which requirements enumerated by the Constraint Templates are unfulfilled by the given SyncSet(s) and Config(s).

The prescription of which resources to sync is done in `SyncSet` resources and/or the Gatekeeper `Config` resource. The management of these various requirements can get challenging as the number of templates requiring replicated data increases. 

`gator sync verify` aims to mitigate this challenge by enabling the user to verify their sync configuration is correct. The user passes in any number of Constraint Templates, SyncSets, and Gatekeeper Config objects (although in practice only one Config object should exist), and the command will determine which requirements enumerated by the Constraint Templates are unfulfilled by the given SyncSet(s) and Config(s).

[PRD](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1mBvy6Y7TDyZswdYlFBHB3Mi2irLVqga_7ZoZvfPIU0A/edit)

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -427,6 +427,80 @@ However, not including the `namespace` definition in the call to `gator expand`
 error expanding resources: error expanding resource nginx-deployment: failed to mutate resultant resource nginx-deployment-pod: matching for mutator Assign.mutations.gatekeeper.sh /always-pull-image failed for  Pod my-ns nginx-deployment-pod: failed to run Match criteria: namespace selector for namespace-scoped object but missing Namespace
 ```
 
+## The `gator sync verify` subcommand
+
+Certain templates require [replicating data](sync.md) into OPA to enable correct evaluation. These templates can use the annotation `metadata.gatekeeper.sh/requires-sync-data` to indicate which resources need to be synced. The annotation contains a json object representing a list of requirements, each of which contains a list of one or more equivalence sets. Each of these equivalence sets has `groups`, `versions`, and `kinds` fields; any group-version-kind combination within an equivalence set within a requirement should be considered sufficient to satisfy that requirement. For example (comments added for clarity):
+```
+[
+  [ // Requirement 1
+    { // Equivalence set 1
+      "groups": ["group1", group2"]
+      "versions": ["version1", "version2", "version3"]
+      "kinds": ["kind1", "kind2"]
+    },
+    { // Equivalence Set 2
+      "groups": ["group3", group4"]
+      "versions": ["version3", "version4"]
+      "kinds": ["kind3", "kind4"]
+    }
comment.body:
OK just want to clarify... In the above example, are the [three representations](https://github.com/open-policy-agent/gatekeeper/pull/3098#discussion_r1369368083) all entries in the map of GVKs called `GVKEquivalenceSet` here in the code?

https://github.com/open-policy-agent/gatekeeper/blob/3a83700f287e73376ba264db1cc75d14dd0da8f8/pkg/cachemanager/parser/syncannotationreader.go#L15-L21

If that _isn't_ true, that is a bug.

> at the end of the day I think it still is clearest to be able to call each of the 2 objects within one requirement their own ES, even if they get parsed into a single ES under the hood...thoughts?

I feel the opposite.  IMHO, the terminology should maximize meaning and be extremely true to the intention.

Any set of things that are equivalent is an... `EquivalenceSet`.  If we _don't_ say that, we're saying that an EquivalenceSet is more about how things are written than about what they are.  That's surely confusing.

If we need a name for one of those single JSON structs, let's just make one that is unambiguous: `GVKClause`.  I don't feel strongly about the exact name, I just want us to use our essential terminology (`EquivalenceSet`) wisely.

FWIW, users don't have to specify a type when they make a "GVK Clause", so the naming isn't all that important.  

-------

OH, a further example.  Imagine that Ingress didn't have a `v1` in `networking.k8s.io`.  We'd then write it as:

```
          {
            "groups": ["networking.k8s.io", "extensions"],
            "versions": ["v1beta1"],
            "kinds": ["Ingress"]
          }
```

What was two equivalenceSets became 1.

Another way to think of it is that we could take our current 2 clauses and write them as 3:

```
      "[
        [
          {
            "groups": ["extensions"],
            "versions": ["v1beta1"],
            "kinds": ["Ingress"]
          },
          {
            "groups": ["networking.k8s.io"],
            "versions": ["v1beta1"],
            "kinds": ["Ingress"]
          },
          {
            "groups": ["networking.k8s.io"],
            "versions": ["v1"],
            "kinds": ["Ingress"]
          }
        ]
      ]"
```

Do we now have 3 EQs?  Clearly we still have one set of GVKs which are equivalent to each other.

The management of these various requirements can get challenging as the number of templates requiring replicated data increases. 

`gator sync verify` aims to mitigate this challenge by enabling the user to verify their sync configuration is correct. The user passes in any number of Constraint Templates, SyncSets, and Gatekeeper Config objects (although in practice only one Config object should exist), and the command will determine which requirements enumerated by the Constraint Templates are unfulfilled by the given SyncSet(s) and Config(s).

[PRD](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1mBvy6Y7TDyZswdYlFBHB3Mi2irLVqga_7ZoZvfPIU0A/edit)

**Which issue(s) this PR fixes** *(optional, using `fixes #<issue number>(, fixes #<issue_number>, ...)` format, will close the issue(s) when the PR gets merged)*:
xref #2393 

**Special notes for your reviewer**:
Put ToSyncSet and ToConfig alongside ToConfig; however I did notice some type conversion in [individual command code](https://github.com/open-policy-agent/gatekeeper/blob/master/pkg/gator/expand/expand.go#L232) and I could see that being more correct since this won't be used anywhere else
Wasn't quite sure how to handle discovery results via stdin as they're not Kubernetes unstructureds; would welcome any thoughts there :)

pull_request.body:
**What this PR does / why we need it**:
Certain templates require replicating into OPA to enable correct evaluation. These templates can use the annotation `metadata.gatekeeper.sh/requires-sync-data` to indicate which resources need to be synced. This template annotation is descriptive, not prescriptive. The prescription of which resources to sync is done in `SyncSet` resources and/or the Gatekeeper `Config` resource. The management of these various requirements can get challenging as the number of templates requiring replicated data increases. 

`gator sync verify` aims to mitigate this challenge by enabling the user to verify their sync configuration is correct. The user passes in any number of Constraint Templates, SyncSets, and Gatekeeper Config objects (although in practice only one Config object should exist), and the command will determine which requirements enumerated by the Constraint Templates are unfulfilled by the given SyncSet(s) and Config(s).

[PRD](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1mBvy6Y7TDyZswdYlFBHB3Mi2irLVqga_7ZoZvfPIU0A/edit)

pull_request.body:
**What this PR does / why we need it**:
Certain templates require replicating into OPA to enable correct evaluation. These templates can use the annotation `metadata.gatekeeper.sh/requires-sync-data` to indicate which resources need to be synced. This template annotation is descriptive, not prescriptive. The prescription of which resources to sync is done in `SyncSet` resources and/or the Gatekeeper `Config` resource. The management of these various requirements can get challenging as the number of templates requiring replicated data increases. 

`gator sync verify` aims to mitigate this challenge by enabling the user to verify their sync configuration is correct. The user passes in any number of Constraint Templates, SyncSets, and Gatekeeper Config objects (although in practice only one Config object should exist), and the command will determine which requirements enumerated by the Constraint Templates are unfulfilled by the given SyncSet(s) and Config(s).

[PRD](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1mBvy6Y7TDyZswdYlFBHB3Mi2irLVqga_7ZoZvfPIU0A/edit)

**Which issue(s) this PR fixes** *(optional, using `fixes #<issue number>(, fixes #<issue_number>, ...)` format, will close the issue(s) when the PR gets merged)*:

**Special notes for your reviewer**:
Put ToSyncSet and ToConfig alongside ToConfig; however I did notice some type conversion in [individual command code](https://github.com/open-policy-agent/gatekeeper/blob/master/pkg/gator/expand/expand.go#L232) and I could see that being more correct since this won't be used anywhere else

comment.body:
The example I would draw would be to look at CLIs that manage multiple types of objects and have common actions they do on those objects.  

#### Synonyms don't scale

Let's take the verb `list` as an example.

Imagine that when we were talking about `object-a`, we said `list`.
But then, when we talk about `object-b`, we use some kind of synonym like `inventory` or `enumerate`.  

As we add further types (`object-c`, `object-d`, etc.), this quickly falls over.  I don't have a degree in English and I don't imagine our users do either.

#### Terminology is a feature

While we'd love it if our users didn't have to learn new terminology to use our product, novel functionality often requires learning a novel lexicon.  That is unless you can copy from a lexicon already established in your domain (`kubectl` and `gcloud` both use the verb `describe`, for example).

If we have to establish the meaning of words in our domain, then we should keep those meanings clear and consistent.

If that is done effectively, the terminology becomes a _feature_ of the product.  By learning the terminology, one can successfully navigate the domain.

I'd argue that using a specific word (`verify`) and using that word whenever we are doing what `verify` means in our space is us investing in a consistent lexicon that provides value to our users.  Re-using it (as long as the verb is actually the same for the two nouns) actually _strengthens_ the product.

All that being said, is there some way that this "verification" is meaningfully different than the other "verify"?  Such that a consistent use of the verb is not appropriate?

comment.body:
Personally I like my [proposition](https://github.com/open-policy-agent/gatekeeper/pull/3098#discussion_r1369309334), which differentiates two kinds of errors:

1. "These objects are invalid and I can't interpret them correctly"

2. "These objects are valid but misconfigured"

IMO type 1 should be evaluated first and should stop the command in its tracks.  These errors are kind of "existential", because they prevent correct functioning.  Thus, I think a "fail fast" approach where the error is returned (with no noise about previous templates working or anything like that).

Once everything is known to be valid, errors of type 2 can be collated and printed as a list.  These aren't "errors" as much as they are "valid but negative results".  Thus the differentiation.

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,131 @@
+package verify
+
+import (
+	"testing"
+
+	"github.com/google/go-cmp/cmp"
+	"github.com/open-policy-agent/gatekeeper/v3/pkg/gator/fixtures"
+	"github.com/stretchr/testify/require"
+	"k8s.io/apimachinery/pkg/apis/meta/v1/unstructured"
+	"k8s.io/apimachinery/pkg/util/yaml"
+)
+
+func TestVerify(t *testing.T) {
+	tcs := []struct {
+		name      string
+		inputs    []string
+		discovery string
+		want      map[string][]int
+		err       error
+	}{
+		{
+			name: "basic req unfulfilled",
+			inputs: []string{
+				fixtures.TemplateReferential,
+			},
+			want: map[string][]int{
+				"k8suniqueserviceselector": {1},
+			},
+		},
+		{
+			name: "basic req fulfilled by syncset",
+			inputs: []string{
+				fixtures.TemplateReferential,
+				fixtures.Config,
+			},
+			want: map[string][]int{},
+		},
+		{
+			name: "basic req fulfilled by syncset and discoveryresults",
+			inputs: []string{
+				fixtures.TemplateReferential,
+				fixtures.Config,
+			},
+			discovery: `{"": {"v1": ["Service"]}}`,
+			want:      map[string][]int{},
+		},
+		{
+			name: "basic req fulfilled by syncset but not discoveryresults",
+			inputs: []string{
+				fixtures.TemplateReferential,
+				fixtures.Config,
+			},
+			discovery: `{"extensions": {"v1beta1": ["Ingress"]}}`,
+			want: map[string][]int{
+				"k8suniqueserviceselector": {1},
+			},
+		},
+		{
+			name: "multi equivalentset req fulfilled by syncset",
+			inputs: []string{
+				fixtures.TemplateReferentialMultEquivSets,
+				fixtures.SyncSet,
+			},
+			want: map[string][]int{},
+		},
+		{
+			name: "multi requirement, one req fulfilled by syncset",
+			inputs: []string{
+				fixtures.TemplateReferentialMultReqs,
+				fixtures.SyncSet,
+			},
+			want: map[string][]int{
+				"k8suniqueingresshostmultireq": {2},
+			},
+		},
+		{
+			name: "multiple templates, syncset and config",
+			inputs: []string{
+				fixtures.TemplateReferential,
+				fixtures.TemplateReferentialMultEquivSets,
+				fixtures.TemplateReferentialMultReqs,
+				fixtures.Config,
+				fixtures.SyncSet,
+			},
+			want: map[string][]int{
+				"k8suniqueingresshostmultireq": {2},
+			},
+		},
+		{
+			name:   "no data of any kind",
+			inputs: []string{},
+			want:   map[string][]int{},
+		},
+	}
+
+	for _, tc := range tcs {
+		t.Run(tc.name, func(t *testing.T) {
+			// convert the test resources to unstructureds
+			var objs []*unstructured.Unstructured
+			for _, input := range tc.inputs {
+				u, err := readUnstructured([]byte(input))
+				require.NoError(t, err)
+				objs = append(objs, u)
+			}
+
+			got, err := Verify(objs, tc.discovery)
+			if tc.err != nil {
+				require.ErrorIs(t, err, tc.err)
+			} else if err != nil {
+				require.NoError(t, err)
+			}
+
+			if diff := cmp.Diff(tc.want, got); diff != "" {
+				t.Errorf("diff in missingRequirements objects (-want +got):\n%s", diff)
+			}
+		})
+	}
+}
+
+func readUnstructured(bytes []byte) (*unstructured.Unstructured, error) {
comment.body: Let's leave it cleaner than we found it

pull_request.body:
**What this PR does / why we need it**:
Certain templates require replicating into OPA to enable correct evaluation. These templates can use the annotation `metadata.gatekeeper.sh/requires-sync-data` to indicate which resources need to be synced. This template annotation is descriptive, not prescriptive. The prescription of which resources to sync is done in `SyncSet` resources and/or the Gatekeeper `Config` resource. The management of these various requirements can get challenging as the number of templates requiring replicated data increases. 

`gator sync verify` aims to mitigate this challenge by enabling the user to verify their sync configuration is correct. The user passes in any number of Constraint Templates, SyncSets, and Gatekeeper Config objects (although in practice only one Config object should exist), and the command will determine which requirements enumerated by the Constraint Templates are unfulfilled by the given SyncSet(s) and Config(s).

[PRD](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1mBvy6Y7TDyZswdYlFBHB3Mi2irLVqga_7ZoZvfPIU0A/edit)

issue.title: CVE in Gatekeeper 3.13.3
issue.body:
**What steps did you take and what happened:**
We found the following CVEs in Gatekeeper 3.9.0:

- docker.io/openpolicyagent/gatekeeper:v3.13.3

1.     [CVE-2023-45142](https://github.com/advisories/GHSA-rcjv-mgp8-qvmr)

- docker.io/openpolicyagent/gatekeeper-crds:v3.13.3

1. [CVE-2023-2253](https://github.com/advisories/GHSA-hqxw-f8mx-cpmw)
2. [CVE-2023-3978](https://github.com/advisories/GHSA-2wrh-6pvc-2jm9)
3. [CVE-2023-44487](https://github.com/advisories/GHSA-qppj-fm5r-hxr3)

Could you please upgrade the corresponding components to resolve these CVE's. 

**Anything else you would like to add:**
[Miscellaneous information that will assist in solving the issue.]


**Environment:**

- Gatekeeper version: 3.13.3
- Kubernetes version: (use `kubectl version`):
